defs.etymology: Of native Korean origin.(3rd person pronoun) introduced together with 그녀 (geunyeo) by Kim Dong-in, probably calque of Japanese 彼 (kare), which became a personal pronoun in addition to a demonstrative pronoun due to the influence of European languages.

text: (demonstrative) that (of what has been already said or known)
examples: 그 남자는 일본인입니까 아니면 중국인입니까?  그는 중국인입니다.Geu namjaneun ilboninimnikka animyeon jungguginimnikka? - geuneun jungguginimnida.Is that man Japanese or Chinese? - He is Chinese.
Geu namjaneun ilboninimnikka animyeon jungguginimnikka? - geuneun jungguginimnida.
Is that man Japanese or Chinese? - He is Chinese.
근데 방금 그 여자 누구에요?Geunde banggeum geu yeoja nugueyo?By the way, who is that girl?
Geunde banggeum geu yeoja nugueyo?
By the way, who is that girl?
그 사람들은 가족입니다. ― Geu saramdeureun gajogimnida. ― Those people are family.
그는 아무런 말도 없이 가버렸다.Geuneun amureon maldo eopsi gabeoryeotda.He/She left without saying anything.
Geuneun amureon maldo eopsi gabeoryeotda.
He/She left without saying anything.

defs.etymology:
First attested in the Jīlín lèishì (鷄林類事 / 계림유사), 1103, as Late Old Korean 迺 (Yale: *nay).
In the Hangul script, first attested in the Yongbi eocheonga (龍飛御天歌 / 용비어천가), 1447, as Middle Korean 네〯 (Yale: něy).
Beyond Middle Korean, the reconstruction of the ancestral Koreanic root for "four" is difficult. See a list of relevant attestations and forms in Appendix:Historical Koreanic numerals#Four.

examples: 학생 네 명 ― haksaeng ne myeong ― four students
비둘기 네 마리 ― bidulgi ne mari ― four pigeons
네 개의 그림이 있습니다. ― Ne gae-ui geurim-i itseumnida. ― There are four pictures.

text: Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.
Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.

defs.etymology: Probably from the same source as 예 (ye), plausibly *녜 (*nye) (apparently not directly attested).

examples: 네, 알겠습니다. ― Ne, al-get-seumnida. ― Yes, I understand.

text: Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.
Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.

defs.etymology:
Contractions of:
(nominative): 너 (neo, “you”) +‎ 이 (-i, nominative case marker), which is no longer grammatically accepted.
(genitive): 너 (neo, “you”) +‎ 의 (-ui, genitive case marker).

text: (nominative): 너 (neo, “you”) +‎ 이 (-i, nominative case marker), which is no longer grammatically accepted.
Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.
Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.

defs.etymology: Related to 누구 (nugu), possibly descended from 뉘〯 (Yale: nwǔy).

examples: 야 너는 네 덕에 사는가?Ya neo-neun ne deog-e sa-neun'ga?Hey, thanks to who is it that you live well?
Ya neo-neun ne deog-e sa-neun'ga?
Hey, thanks to who is it that you live well?

defs.etymology: Sino-Korean word from 去 (“last”) + 夜 (“night”)

text: Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.
Contraction of 조금 (jogeum): a little; somewhat; quite
a little while, a short time
(used to soften requests) please; if you wouldn't mind
examples: 좀 있다가 전화할께요.Jom itdaga jeonhwahalkkeyo.I'll call you in a little while.
Jom itdaga jeonhwahalkkeyo.
I'll call you in a little while.
좀만 더하면 끝나겠는데?Jomman deohamyeon kkeunnagenneunde?A little more and it'll be over?
Jomman deohamyeon kkeunnagenneunde?
A little more and it'll be over?

text: moth, bookworm; general term for any insect which eats fabrics, paper etc.
examples: 양복이 좀이 쏠다.Yangbogi jomi ssolda.The clothes become moth-eaten.” .
Yangbogi jomi ssolda.
The clothes become moth-eaten.” .
응, 그래.Eung, geurae.Yeah, okay.
Eung, geurae.
Yeah, okay.
그래? 미처 생각도 못했네.Geurae? Micheo saenggakdo mothaenne.Really?  didn't really think about that either.
Geurae? Micheo saenggakdo mothaenne.
Really?  didn't really think about that either.

text: 해체 (haeche, “informal”) present tense form of 있다 (itda, “to exist”)

defs.etymology: Of native Korean origin.

examples: 너는 이 가수를 왜 좋아해?Neo-neun i gasu-reul wae joahae?Why do you like this singer?
Neo-neun i gasu-reul wae joahae?
Why do you like this singer?
그것으로는 네가 왜 전화를 안 했는지 설명이 안 돼.Geugeos-euro-neun ne-ga wae jeonhwareul an haenneunji seolmyeong-i an dwae.That doesn't explain why you didn't phone.
Geugeos-euro-neun ne-ga wae jeonhwareul an haenneunji seolmyeong-i an dwae.
That doesn't explain why you didn't phone.

text: Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.

defs.etymology: Korean reading of various Chinese characters.
First attested in the Seokbo sangjeol (釋譜詳節 / 석보상절), 1447, as Middle Korean 더 (Yale: tè).

examples: Antonym: 덜
좀만 더 기다리자. ― Jom-man deo gidarija. ― Let's wait just a bit more.
한 번 더 해봐. ― Han beon deo haebwa. ― Try one more time.
오늘이 어제보다 더 춥다. ― Oneur-i eojeboda deo chupda. ― Today is colder than yesterday.

defs.etymology: Of native Korean origin. From same root as 그 (geu, “that”) and 그렇다 (geureota).

text: and, also, in addition (often used at the beginning of a sentence)

defs.etymology:
From Middle Korean 우리 (wuli), from Old Korean 吾里 (*WUli), from Old Korean 又 (*wu) + unknown suffix *-li. The root is different from the singular first-person pronoun, 나 (na).
In Hangul form: First attested in the Yongbi eocheonga (龍飛御天歌 / 용비어천가), 1447, as Middle Korean 우리 (Yale: wuli).

text: (when referring to one's own family members) my
examples: 우리 어머니는 이번 주에 마을에 계십니다.Uri eomeonineun ibeon ju-e ma'eure gyesimnida.My mother is in town this week.
Uri eomeonineun ibeon ju-e ma'eure gyesimnida.
My mother is in town this week.

defs.etymology: First attested in the Hunmong jahoe (訓蒙字會 / 훈몽자회), 1527, as Middle Korean 우리 (Yale: wuli).
First attested in the Yongbi eocheonga (龍飛御天歌 / 용비어천가), 1447, as Middle Korean 다〯 (Yale: tǎ).

text: used to express mild surprise or sarcasm
with a verb in the past tense, used sarcastically to emphasize that the verb has not occurred
examples: Synonym: 모두
청소를 다 했다. ― Cheongso-reul da haetda. ― I finished cleaning everything.
나는 다 먹을 생각이다. ― Na-neun da meogeul saenggag-ida. ― I'm thinking of eating it all.
집에 다 와 간다. ― Jib-e da wa ganda. ― I'm basically home [e.g. outside the door].
이런 미친 놈이 다 있네.Ireon michin nom-i da in-ne.I can't believe this bastard is so crazy.
Ireon michin nom-i da in-ne.
I can't believe this bastard is so crazy.
애들이 놀자니까 잠은 다 잤다.Ae-deur-i nol-ja-nikka jam-eun da jatda.The kids are asking me to play, so that's it for my plans for a nap.”)
Ae-deur-i nol-ja-nikka jam-eun da jatda.
The kids are asking me to play, so that's it for my plans for a nap.

text: everything, all (only before the copulas 이다 (ida, “to be”) and 아니다 (anida, “to not be”))
examples: Synonym: 전부
그게 다냐? ― Geuge da-nya? ― Is that all?
성공은 인생의 다가 아니다. ― Seonggong-eun insaeng-ui da-ga anida. ― Success is not everything of life.

text: Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.

defs.etymology: Sino-Korean word from 多.

text: Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.

defs.etymology: 다 is the third syllable in the conventional ordering of Hangul, just as C is the third letter of the Roman alphabet.

text: Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.
(speech of the royal court) scorched rice tea, sungnyung
Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.

defs.etymology: Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

First attested in the Gwonyyeom yorok (勸念要錄 / 권념요록), 1637, as Early Modern Korean 므슨 (Yale: musun), probably a hypercorrection of Middle Korean 므슴〮 (Yale: mùsúm) that was motivated by the adnominal suffix 은 (-eun) common in determiners.
Variants of 므슴〮 (Yale: mùsúm) with final ㅁ (m), e.g. 무슴 (museum) and 무삼 (musam), remained more common than 므슨 or 무슨 until the mid-nineteenth century and are still used by some older speakers of Gyeongsang dialect.

text: (in statements) a certain, some; some kind of
what kind of; used for emphasis in a rhetorical question.
examples: 무슨 일을 하세요?Museun ir-eul haseyo?What kind of work do you do?
Museun ir-eul haseyo?
What kind of work do you do?
무슨 일이 있어서 못 왔어.Museun ir-i iss-eoseo mot wasseo.He couldn't come because he had some sort of work [to do].
Museun ir-i iss-eoseo mot wasseo.
He couldn't come because he had some sort of work [to do].
내가 그 짓을 하면 무슨 사람이 되는 거겠어?Nae-ga geu jis-eul ha-myeon museun saram-i doeneun geo-gess-eo?If I did that, what kind of person would I be?
Nae-ga geu jis-eul ha-myeon museun saram-i doeneun geo-gess-eo?
If I did that, what kind of person would I be?

defs.etymology: From Middle Korean ᄒᆞᆫ (hòn).

text: one (as a determiner numeral before a noun or classifier)
examples: 새 한 마리가 날아간다.Sae han mari-ga naraganda.A bird is flying away.
Sae han mari-ga naraganda.
A bird is flying away.
Synonym: 대략

defs.etymology: Sino-Korean word from 限, from the Middle Korean reading ᄒᆞᆫ (Yale: hon).

text: being as long as; being as far as
a word used to indicate that the extent of what is referred to in the preceding statement is beyond measure
a word used to indicate a situation in which one is expected to sacrifice oneself for a certain task or endure a difficult and painful circumstance
examples: 그것이 한이다.Geugeos-i han-ida.That is the limit.
Geugeos-i han-ida.
That is the limit.
내가 알고 있는 한, ...Nae-ga algo inneun han, ...As far as I've been informed ...
Nae-ga algo inneun han, ...

defs.etymology: 하 (ha-) +‎ 지만 (-jiman).

text: does, but...; see 하다 (hada) and 지만 (-jiman).

defs.etymology: Of native Korean origin.

text: at a good time, with fortunate timing
examples: Geurimeul aju jal geurinda.

defs.etymology: Abbreviation of 자루 (jaru)
From 어떻 (eotteot-, “(to be) in what state; (to be) how”) +‎ 게 (-ge, adverbial suffix).

examples: 내가 그 시험에 어떻게 통과하지?Nae-ga geu siheom-e eotteoke tonggwa-haji?How can I pass the exam?
Nae-ga geu siheom-e eotteoke tonggwa-haji?
How can I pass the exam?

안녕, 피트. 어떻게 지내? 안녕 아나. 좋아. 넌 어떻게 지내? 굉장히 잘 지내.Annyeong, piteu. Eotteoke jinae? Annyeong ana. Joa. Neon eotteoke jinae? Goengjanghi jal jinae.Oh, hi, Pete. How’s it going? —  Hi, Anna. It’s going great. How’s it going with you? — Things are awesome!Original English texts from 2016, VOA Learning English
Annyeong, piteu. Eotteoke jinae? Annyeong ana. Joa. Neon eotteoke jinae? Goengjanghi jal jinae.
Oh, hi, Pete. How’s it going? —  Hi, Anna. It’s going great. How’s it going with you? — Things are awesome!
Original English texts from 2016, VOA Learning English
성함이 어떻게 되세요?Seonghami eotteoke doeseyo?What is your name?
Seonghami eotteoke doeseyo?
What is your name?
나이가 어떻게 되세요?Naiga eotteoke doeseyo?What is your age?
Naiga eotteoke doeseyo?
What is your age?
이 컴퓨터는 가격이 어떻게 됩니까?I keompyuteo-neun gagyeog-i eotteoke doemnikka?How much is this computer?
I keompyuteo-neun gagyeog-i eotteoke doemnikka?
How much is this computer?
Ijayuri eotteoke doejiyo?
What is the interest rate?
어떻게 오셨어요?Eotteoke osyeosseoyo?What brings you here? Why have you come?
Eotteoke osyeosseoyo?
What brings you here? Why have you come?

defs.etymology: Korean reading of various Chinese characters.
(This etymology is missing or incomplete. Please add to it, or discuss it at the Etymology scriptorium.)Semantically compare Japanese ただ (tada, “simply; free”)

text: simply; just like that; just as it is.

defs.etymology: 정(正) (jeong, “something that is correct”) +‎ 말 (mal, “word”).

examples: 새 하인들은 일을 정말 잘 해.Sae hain-deur-eun ir-eul jeongmal jal hae.Those new servants really do a splendid job.
Sae hain-deur-eun ir-eul jeongmal jal hae.
Those new servants really do a splendid job.

text: that which is true or genuine
examples: 그거 정말이야? ― Geugeo jeongmar-i-ya? ― Is that true?

text: Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.

defs.etymology: Contraction of 그러면 (geureomyeon, “if so”)

First attested in the Seokbo sangjeol (釋譜詳節 / 석보상절), 1447, as Middle Korean 것 (Yale: kès). Compare Japanese 事 (koto, “abstract thing”).
The now colloquially dominant contraction 거 (geo) is first attested in the nineteenth century.
From Middle Korean 잇다 (ista), from Old Korean 有叱 (*Is-). Related to the past tense marker 었 (-eot).

text: to be (in a place); to exist
(auxiliary, after the 어/아 (-eo/a) infinitive) to be (in a state)
(auxiliary, after the 고 (-go) connective) to be in the process of
examples: 뉴욕은 미국에 있다.Nyuyog-eun Migug-e itda.New York is in the United States.
Nyuyog-eun Migug-e itda.
New York is in the United States.
물속에 물고기가 있다.Mulsog-e mulgogi-ga itda.There are fish in the water.
Mulsog-e mulgogi-ga itda.
There are fish in the water.
Antonym: 없다
그녀는 남자친구가 있다.Geunyeo-neun namjachin'gu-ga itda.She has a boyfriend.
Geunyeo-neun namjachin'gu-ga itda.
She has a boyfriend.
저는 집도 있고 차도 있어요.Jeo-neun jip-do itgo cha-do isseoyo.I have a house and a car.
Jeo-neun jip-do itgo cha-do isseoyo.
I have a house and a car.
Antonym: 없다
죽어 있다 ― jugeo itda ― to be dead
모여 있다 ― moyeo itda ― to be gathered together
죽고 있다 ― jukgo itda ― to be dying
모이고 있다 ― moigo itda ― to be gathering together

defs.etymology: First attested in the Seokbo sangjeol (釋譜詳節 / 석보상절), 1447, as Middle Korean 이ᅌᅥ긔〮 (Yale: ì.ngè.kúy).

examples: 그래, 나 여기 있어. — 좋아, 너 거기 있구나.Geurae, na yeogi isseo. — joa, neo geogi itguna.Oh, yes. I am here! — Good. You are there.Original English texts from 2016, VOA Learning English
Geurae, na yeogi isseo. — joa, neo geogi itguna.
Oh, yes. I am here! — Good. You are there.
Original English texts from 2016, VOA Learning English

defs.etymology: First attested in the Yongbi eocheonga (龍飛御天歌 / 용비어천가), 1447, as Middle Korean 날〮 (Yale: nál), presumably from Old Korean 日尸 (*NAlh).

text: day (twenty-four hours, a thirtieth of the month)
weather (mainly with adjectives describing the weather's state)
examples: 그는 날마다 일하러 간다.Geu-neun nalmada ilhareo ganda.He goes to work every day.
Geu-neun nalmada ilhareo ganda.
He goes to work every day.
우리 만나기로 한 날이 며칠이지?Uri mannagiro han nar-i myeochir-iji?When's the day we planned on meeting up?
Uri mannagiro han nar-i myeochir-iji?
When's the day we planned on meeting up?
날이 안 좋다.Nar-i an jota.The weather is bad.
Nar-i an jota.
The weather is bad.
Synonym:  날씨
Synonym:  낮

defs.etymology: First attested in the Worin cheongangjigok (月印千江之曲 / 월인천강지곡), 1449, as Middle Korean ᄂᆞᆶ〮 (Yale: nólh). Possibly related to Old Japanese な (na, “blade”).

examples: Synonym: 칼날 ”)

defs.etymology: First attested in the Neung-eomgyeong eonhae (楞嚴經諺解 / 능엄경언해), 1461, as Middle Korean ᄂᆞᆶ〮 (Yale: nólh).

text: warp, the longitudinal threads of woven cloth
examples: Antonym: 씨

defs.etymology: First attested in the Neung-eomgyeong eonhae (楞嚴經諺解 / 능엄경언해), 1461, as Middle Korean ᄂᆞᆯ (Yale: nòl). Possibly related to Japanese 生 (nama, “raw”), 菜 (na, “greens as a food; side dish”) and 生る (naru, “to bear fruit”).

text: Only used in 날로 (nallo, “as something raw, as something uncooked”)
(colloquial) Alternative form of 나를 (nareul, “me”, first-person singular pronoun used as a direct object)

defs.etymology: See the main entries.

text: Future adnominal of 나다 (nada, “to exit”): which will exit
Future adnominal of 날다 (nalda, “to fly”): which will fly

defs.etymology: Modern Korean reading of various Chinese characters, from the Middle Korean reading 날 (Yale: nal).

Modern South Korean reading of various Chinese characters in isolation or as the first element of a compound, which was also true of most dialects (both North and South) in 1945. From Middle Korean 랄 (Yale: lal); when preceded by another character in a compound, they retain the original 랄 (ral) form.
In the North Korean standard, they are always read as 랄 (ral), but this is an artificial imposition intended to standardize Sino-Korean readings, which did not reflect any major dialect's pronunciation in 1945.
걸 (geol-) +‎ ㄴ (-n).

text: past determinative of 걸다 (geolda, “to speak or suspend”): having been suspended, spoken; of a telephone call, having been made
examples: 내가 건 전화 ― naega geon jeonhwa ― the call I made

defs.etymology: 걸 (geol-) +‎ ㄴ (-n).

text: determinative of 걸다 (geolda, “to be fertile or sumptuous”): rich, fertile, sumptuous

defs.etymology: 거 (geo) +‎ ㄴ (-n).
Sino-Korean word from 乾
Sino-Korean word from 件
Sino-Korean word from 前, from the Middle Korean reading 젼 (Yale: cyen).

examples: 집에 가기 전에jib-e gagi jeonebefore going home
jib-e gagi jeone
before going home
두시 15분 전에dusi sibobun jeoneat a quarter to two
dusi sibobun jeone
at a quarter to two
전에는 그를 봤었다. 그러나 그 이후로는 그를 보지 않았다.Jeon-eneun geu-reul bwasseotda. Geureona geu ihu-ro-neun geu-reul boji anatda.I had seen him previously, but hadn't seen him since.
Jeon-eneun geu-reul bwasseotda. Geureona geu ihu-ro-neun geu-reul boji anatda.
I had seen him previously, but hadn't seen him since.
전에 보안관 뱃지는 본 적이 없습니다. ― Jeone boan'gwan baetjineun bon jeogi eopseumnida. ― I’ve never seen a Marshal’s badge before.
전 대통령jeon daetongnyeongex-president
jeon daetongnyeong

examples: 아니 가다 ― ani gada ― not to go

defs.etymology: First attested in the Yongbi eocheonga (龍飛御天歌 / 용비어천가), 1447, as Middle Korean 뎌 (Yale: tye).
Of native Korean origin.

examples: 저는 아까 다리를 저는 사람을 보았습니다.Jeo-neun akka dari-reul jeoneun saram-eul boatseumnida.I saw someone limping earlier.

defs.etymology: First attested in the Beonyeok sohak (飜譯小學 / 번역소학), 1517, as Middle Korean 져 (Yale: cye). From Literary Chinese 箸.
Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

저 (jeo, “I; me”, humble first-person pronoun) +‎ 이 (i, nominative particle). When the 가 (ga) allomorph of the nominative particle was introduced, it was attached to the already marked form of 저, producing this new allomorphy.

text: allomorph of 저 (jeo, humble first-person pronoun) before 가 (ga, nominative suffix)
examples: 선생님, 제가 그랬습니다.Seonsaengnim, je-ga geurasseumnida.Teacher, it was I who did that.
Seonsaengnim, je-ga geurasseumnida.
Teacher, it was I who did that.

defs.etymology: Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

examples: I imenyuneun 3gae'ui dareun eoneoro sseuyeojeo itda.
This e-menu is written in three different languages.

defs.etymology: Determinative form of 그렇다 (geureota, “to be thus”).

First attested in the Seokbo sangjeol (釋譜詳節 / 석보상절), 1447, as Middle Korean 너무 (Yale: nèmwù), from Middle Korean 넘〯— (Yale: něm, “to surpass”, whence modern 넘다 (neomda)) + 우 (Yale: -wu, adverb-deriving suffix), but now perceived as a single morpheme.

examples: 너무도 예쁘다neomu-do yeppeudaso very beautiful
neomu-do yeppeuda
so very beautiful

defs.etymology: Regular derivative of 그렇다 (geureota, “to be like that”), formed by joining the suffix 서 (seo) to the connective stem form 그래 (geurae).

text: therefore, accordingly, because of that, because things are like that
in that way, to that extent
examples: 나는 그렇게 생각하지 않아.Naneun geureoke saenggakhaji ana.I don't think so.
Naneun geureoke saenggakhaji ana.
I don't think so.
난 정말 그렇게 하기는 원하지 않아.Nan jeongmal geureoke hagineun wonhaji ana.I really do not want to do that.
Nan jeongmal geureoke hagineun wonhaji ana.
I really do not want to do that.

defs.etymology: Of native Korean origin.

examples: 죄송한데 제가 잘 못 들었거든요, 다시 말씀해 주시겠어요?Joesonghande jega jal mot deureotgeodeunyo, dasi malsseumhae jusigesseoyo?Sorry, I didn't hear you. Can you say that again please?
Joesonghande jega jal mot deureotgeodeunyo, dasi malsseumhae jusigesseoyo?
Sorry, I didn't hear you. Can you say that again please?

defs.etymology: Borrowed from Japanese ダッシュ (dasshu), from English dash.
First attested in the Hunmin jeongeum eonhae (訓民正音諺解本 / 훈민정음언해본), 1446, as Middle Korean 이런 (Yale: ilen). From 이렇다 (ireota, “to be like this”).

text: weak expression of frustration/disgust; compare darn, oh no, shucks
examples: 이런! 내가 더이상 실수하지 않았으면 좋겠는데.Ireon! Naega deoisang silsuhaji anasseumyeon jokenneunde.Darn it! I hope I wouldn't make any mistakes anymore.
Ireon! Naega deoisang silsuhaji anasseumyeon jokenneunde.
Darn it! I hope I wouldn't make any mistakes anymore.

defs.etymology: First attested in the Seokbo sangjeol (釋譜詳節 / 석보상절), 1447, as Middle Korean 모ᄃᆞᆫ〮 (Yale: mwòtón), originally the realis adnominal inflection of the verb 몯다〮 (mwòttá, “to gather, to assemble”), hence literally "[the] assembled", but never perceived as such by modern speakers.

examples: 모든 길은 로마로 통한다.Modeun gir-eun roma-ro tonghanda.all roads lead to Rome
Modeun gir-eun roma-ro tonghanda.
all roads lead to Rome

Uri-neun Dangsin-bakke Moreunda

defs.etymology:
First attested in the Yongbi eocheonga (龍飛御天歌 / 용비어천가), 1447, as Middle Korean 둏〯다〮 (Yale: tyǒhtá). Also attested in the Bullyu dugongbu si eonhae (分類杜工部詩諺解 / 분류두공부시언해), 1481, as Middle Korean 됴〯ᄒᆞ다〮 (Yale: tyǒ-hòtá).
됴〯ᄒᆞ다〮 appears to be the older form, cf. 만ᄒᆞ다 (Yale: man-hota) > 많다 (manta), ᄀᆞᆮᄒᆞ다 (Yale: kot-hota) > 같다 (gatda). This is a compound of the unknown element 됴〯 (Yale: tyǒ), potentially a Chinese character that underwent semantic nativisation given that this syllable does not occur in any other native Middle Korean word, and the adjective-deriving light verb ᄒᆞ다〮 (Yale: hòtá), modern 하다 (hada).

good (Having qualities that are good for the body or health.)

good; nice (The word used to express negation of, dissatisfaction with, a situation which has just been mentioned.)
suitable; fit (Appropriate for using as a material or doing something.)

examples: 그는 어렸을 때의 추억에 잠겼다.Geu-neun eoryeosseul ttae-ui chueog-e jamgyeotda.He is reminiscing about his childhood memories.

defs.etymology: First attested in the Seokbo sangjeol (釋譜詳節 / 석보상절), 1447, as Middle Korean ᄠᆡ〮 (Yale: ptóy).

text: dirt, especially dead skin produced by exfoliation

defs.etymology:
From Middle Korean 너 (nè, “you”). Presumably existed in Old Korean, but cannot be ascertained because Old Korean pronouns were written with Chinese logograms that obscure the pronunciation.
It has been suggested since the 1950s that the basic Korean pronouns 나 (na, “I; me”), 너 (neo, “you”), and 누 (nu, “who”) (> modern 누구 (nugu)) were all formed from the same etymon via ablaut, which appears to have once been an extremely productive process in Korean, at some very ancient stage. Given the very limited data on prehistoric Korean, this hypothesis cannot be proven for sure either way.
Possibly cognate with Old Japanese 汝 (na, “you”, second-person singular informal pronoun); if so, generally assumed to be a Koreanic loan into Japanese, given the paucity of Ryukyuan cognates (Vovin 2010).

words: 너희 (neohui), 너희들 (neohuideul) - second-person plural informal pronoun

examples: 너를 사랑해.Neo-reul saranghae.I love you.
Neo-reul saranghae.
I love you.

Neo eonje-buteo dambae piugi sijakhayeonni?
When did you start smoking?
너는 왜 말하지 않니?Neo-neun wae malhaji anni?Why aren't you saying anything?
Neo-neun wae malhaji anni?

너는 아까 빨래 너는 사람 봤어?Neo-neun akka ppallae neoneun saram bwasseo?Did you see someone speading out the laundary earlier?

examples: 아니야, 날 기다리지 말고 먼저 가게.Aniya, nal gidariji malgo meonjeo gage.No, don't wait for me; go first.

defs.etymology: First attested in the Worin cheongangjigok (月印千江之曲 / 월인천강지곡), 1449, as Middle Korean ᄀᆞ티 (Yale: kothi), equivalent to 같 (gat-, “to be the same”) +‎ 이 (-i, adverb-deriving suffix).

examples: 선생님과 같이 기념 사진을 찍었다.Seonsaengnim-gwa gachi ginyeom sajin-eul jjigeotda.We took a commemorative photo with our teacher.
Seonsaengnim-gwa gachi ginyeom sajin-eul jjigeotda.
We took a commemorative photo with our teacher.

defs.etymology: Unknown. Perhaps related to Middle Korean 에ᇰ (Yale: eyng)?

Annyeong jonadan, bappa? - eung, nan bappa.
Hi, Jonathan. Are you busy? - Yes, I’m busy.

defs.etymology: Contraction of 이것 + 이 (igeot + i).

text: this thing (as the subject of the sentence or clause)

defs.etymology: A contraction of 괜 (gwaen) [＜ 공연 (空然, gong'yeon, “in vain, unnecessariness”), (> 괜하— (gwaenha-, “useless, futile”))] + 하— (ha-, “to do”) + —지 (-ji, connective suffix for negative verbs/adjectives) + 아니— (ani-, “to be not”) + 하— (ha-, “to do”) + —다 (-da, citation form ending). Equivalent to 괜 (gwaen) + —찮다 (-chanta).

(of a person) to be allowed to ...; may, can; it is OK to ...

defs.etymology: First attested in the Seokbo sangjeol (釋譜詳節 / 석보상절), 1447, as Middle Korean 오ᄂᆞᆯ〮 (Yale: wònól), from 온〮 (Yale: wón, “which has come”, adnominal form of "to come") + Proto-Koreanic *hoL (“day”), etymologically "day that has come". Cognate with Jeju 오널 (oneol).

examples: 오늘은 4월 3일입니다.Oneur-eun 4wol 3ir-imnida.Today is April the third.

defs.etymology: From French nougat.
누 (nu, “who”) +‎ 가 (-ga, nominative case marker).

No one can stop it with any words.
어떤 사물이나 일의 실제 모습이나 상태.Eotteon samurina irui silje moseubina sangtae.The true nature or state of a certain object or affair.
Eotteon samurina irui silje moseubina sangtae.
The true nature or state of a certain object or affair.
덕택에 저는 아주 잘 지내고 있습니다. 감사해요.Deoktaege jeoneun aju jal jinaego itseumnida. Gamsahaeyo.It's going very well, thank you.
Deoktaege jeoneun aju jal jinaego itseumnida. Gamsahaeyo.

집이 아주 많이 부서졌다.Jibi aju mani buseojeotda.The house is quite damaged.
Jibi aju mani buseojeotda.

defs.etymology: First attested in the Yongbi eocheonga (龍飛御天歌 / 용비어천가), 1447, as Middle Korean 말〯 (Yale: mǎl). The rising pitch implies an earlier bisyllabic origin.

examples: 내 말을 주의하여 들어봐.Nae mareul juuihayeo deureobwa.Listen to me carefully.
Nae mareul juuihayeo deureobwa.
Listen to me carefully.
일본 말을 어디서 배웠어?Ilbon mareul eodiseo baewosseo?Where did you learn Japanese?
Ilbon mareul eodiseo baewosseo?
Where did you learn Japanese?
Synonym:  어

text: Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.

defs.etymology:
First attested in the Yongbi eocheonga (龍飛御天歌 / 용비어천가), 1447, as Middle Korean ᄆᆞᆯ (Yale: mòl).
Similar words are found across Eurasia. Compare Manchu ᠮᠣᡵᡳᠨ (morin, “horse”), Mongolian морь (mori, “horse”), Nivkh мурӈ (murŋ, “horse”), Old Chinese 馬 (*mraːʔ, “horse”), Japanese 馬 (uma, “horse”), and Proto-Indo-European *márkos (“horse”); see the last link for more.
For the prefix, compare Chinese 馬／马 (mǎ, “horse; big, great”), from which it is perhaps calqued.

text: Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.

defs.etymology:
First attested in the Seokbo sangjeol (釋譜詳節 / 석보상절), 1447, as Middle Korean 말〮 (Yale: mál).
Native Korean related to Sino-Korean 斗. Auxiliary units of quantification of 되 (升, doe).
(Can this(+) etymology be sourced?)

text: Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.

defs.etymology: From Middle Korean 맗 (malh). Short form of 말뚝 (malttuk).

text: Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.

defs.etymology: First attested in the Hunmong jahoe (訓蒙字會 / 훈몽자회), 1527, as Middle Korean ᄆᆞᆯ〮 (Yale: mól).

text: an alga or other waterborne cryptogam
Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.

text: Though still prescriptive in Standard Korean, most speakers in both Koreas no longer distinguish vowel length.

defs.etymology: Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

First attested in the Worin seokbo (月印釋譜 / 월인석보), 1459, as Middle Korean 아직〮 (Yale: àcík), also attested as 안ᄌᆞᆨ〮 (Yale: àncók), 안직〮 (Yale: àncík). All three MK forms are preserved in various dialects, but only the non-nasal one is accepted in the standard Seoul variety.

text: (with an explicit or implicit negative verb) yet, not yet
examples: "아직도 한참 남은 일이라서, 지금은 그것에 대해서 생각하지 않고 있어요"라고 말했다.Ajikdo hancham nameun iriraseo, jigeum-eun geugeos-e daehaeseo saenggakhaji anko isseoyorago malhaetda."I'm not currently thinking about it because there's still a long way to go," he said.
Ajikdo hancham nameun iriraseo, jigeum-eun geugeos-e daehaeseo saenggakhaji anko isseoyorago malhaetda.
"I'm not currently thinking about it because there's still a long way to go," he said.
아이가 있습니까? — 아니요, 아직 없습니다.Aiga itseumnikka? - Aniyo, ajik eopseumnida.Do you have children? — No, not yet.
Aiga itseumnikka? - Aniyo, ajik eopseumnida.
Do you have children? — No, not yet.
해 떴어? — 아직.Hae tteosseo? - Ajik.Has the sun come up? — Not yet.
Hae tteosseo? - Ajik.
Has the sun come up? — Not yet.

defs.etymology:
진(眞) (jin, “truth”) +‎ 짜 (-jja) of unclear origin, perhaps nativisation of 자(字) (ja, “character”, Sino-Korean).
Presumably replaced Middle Korean 진딧 (cintis), from the same Chinese etymon and with the same meaning.

text: That which is real or actual.

defs.etymology: First attested in the Neung-eomgyeong eonhae (楞嚴經諺解 / 능엄경언해), 1461, as Middle Korean 모도 (Yale: mwotwo).

examples: 그림은 모두 네 개입니다. ― Geurimeun modu ne gaeimnida. ― There are four pictures in total.

“어떻게 생각해? 이것은 굉장한 소식이야. 우리 모두가 좋아하는 어떤 사람에 대한 중요한 소식이라구.”“eotteoke saenggakhae? Igeoseun goengjanghan sosigiya. Uri moduga joahaneun eotteon sarame daehan jung'yohan sosigiragu.”“What do you think? It is excellent news, capital news, and about a certain person we all like.”
“eotteoke saenggakhae? Igeoseun goengjanghan sosigiya. Uri moduga joahaneun eotteon sarame daehan jung'yohan sosigiragu.”
“What do you think? It is excellent news, capital news, and about a certain person we all like.”
같은 말을 되풀이하다gateun mar-eul doepurihadato say the same thing over and over
gateun mar-eul doepurihada
to say the same thing over and over
